body:
Comment 17: 
If you import the same package using two different import strings, then you have two
packages, both built from the same source code, that look identical, but that
nevertheless have different types and different global variables.  That is by design. 
The import string determines the package.

You are saying that we should have a different rule for the main package itself.  We
*could* have a different rule, but why *should* we?

Suppose you import the main package twice, under two different names.  By the existing
rules, you have two different packages.  Now suppose we want to make one of those
packages be the same as the main package running the program.  Which one should we pick?
 We could pick the install name as you suggested in comment #13, but why is that the
right thing to do?

Please don't give an argument based on the obviously right thing to do.  I don't see any
obviously right thing to do here.  To me the most natural choice is the one we have
already made.
